comments.commentBody: I love this variation for its candor!  THE issue, as far as I'm concerned, is not the ability to make a fabulous roast chicken at home, but being able to do so without creating a smoke storm in the kitchen and having to clean your oven AGAIN the next day.  And sad to say, I really haven't found that method.

Interesting twofer tie-in.

Long ikebana class today. We spent an hour gossiping about the visiting professor who taught the recent master class. Sensei loves to gossip.

Only 20% of the 1.6 billion Muslims in the world are Arabs.

The nations with the most Muslims-Indonesia, Pakistan, India and Bangladesh- are all parliamentary democracies that had or have female heads of state and/or government.

What was the "Christian" faith of Jim Jones, David Koresh, Tim McVeigh, Randy Weaver, Eric Frein, Eric Rudolph, Dylann Roof and Cliven Bundy?

What is your faith?

I'm not arguing for complacency, but our current measures are extraordinary by any measure. We cannot let a single attack in Belgium, probably the most vulnerable state in Europe, dictate major security decisions and long-term strategy in the US. Our challenges are totally unique: An ocean separates us from Middle East conflicts, so we do not have droves of returning foreign fighters. We do monitor our borders - not perfectly, but they are nowhere near as porous as European nations. Our intelligence network and investment in homeland security dwarfs that in any other country on the planet; hundreds of Belgian professionals do the job that many thousands perform in the US and abroad. Take a look at the screening process for Syrian refugees relocating to the US, and tell me that it's anywhere NEAR as lax as refugee policies in Europe.

Our security policies since 2001 have either prevented or foiled every major organized terror plot involving foreign attackers. Conversely, we have demonstrated time and time again that we are vulnerable to radicalized lone-wolves already on our soil. Security measures that promote further radicalization will do more to hinder our goals than advance them.
It's a very negligently policy. Europe has enabled terrorism , though the vict are blameless the governments are not. Europe richly deserves its fate.

I don't understand why these European countries have allowed the return of unauthorized travelers to a list of banned Middle East countries, regardless of what EU rules specify about borders.  I'd think the danger these people pose are far greater than any resulting EU censure.

"please remember that the perpetrators in Paris were born and raised in Europe."
The locations on the map where they were born are certainly in Europe, but the reality they live in is worlds apart from most Europeans.
Agreed, but …. have you ever read 'King Leopold's Ghost'?
I agree with other people who think this is a lot of food for 4 people or a lot of broth.
Who cares? There were apparently NO Muslim voices opposing terrorism in the communities where these guys lived, ate, hid, and planned their horrible deeds. That's all that really matters.

There is a famous Japanese haiku poem, "Little snail, climb Mt. Fuji -- slowly, slowly."
Obama has started the U.S. on a climb from the WASP-domination of its past from the perversion of self-determination that doomed the poor, from the post WWII economic and military power over all other nations m-- climb, really renewed climb to a better life as a better nation among equals. FDR, TR, Clinton, LBJ -- he joins others who also disdained "Exceptionalism" an d sought... a mountain to climb. Slowly, slowly. Imagine what Obama might have done with cooperation in Congress and without corporations-as-people.
We must vote to carry on.
Correcton:    ... I AM troubled to see...

Sorry jah8, I realize I didn't answer your question. I have 2 thoughts on security measures:
1) The best defense is a good offense, and our best offense absolutely requires cooperation with Muslim groups and nations. Xenophobia, arrogance, closed borders - none of these things promote the good will required for these partnerships.
2) Terrorism is a hydra: cut off one head, and two will replace it. It is no single group or state, and radical ideologies will flourish as long as conditions allow. I'm not so hopelessly naive that I would suggest that being nice will keep us safe, but positive relations with Muslim people and governments must be a component of our long-term strategy.

It doesn't seem like many people agree with me today... I'm interested to hear your thoughts.

.
I find myself in agreement with Art Kraus and -- possibly a first -- the Canadian duo of Robert and Robert (at least one of whom has a doctorate).

Mr./Dr. Kraus, you may submit a correction for photo captions any time they appear. Wordplay photo captions are corrected every now and then, although the only important one involved a photo of Brett Favre a few days after the Jets signed him.

I would submit the correction myself, but for the fact that I believe the Corrections Desk ignores my emails by now. They are not alone. I was flipping through the Pulitzer Prize website of an afternoon, trying to learn why there is no prize for crossword commentary, when I happened upon a photo with an inaccurate caption. I called in to the office at the journalism school that handles such matters, and reported the error. The person on the phone said she would inform "the tech". So a year later, I learned that the person in the photo was the top editor of a major paper. I checked the Pulitzer site to see if the photo was still there. It was, with the inaccurate caption. So I telephoned the major paper. I asked the person on the other end whether she would be able to transmit info to the editor. When she said yes, I gave her the URL of the photo and asked her to do whatever she wished with the information. It was, after all, her boss in the photo, not me.

Five hours later, I checked the photo. The caption had been fixed.

Robert & Robert: Thank you for the new phrase! "Sun dog."

Are you kidding?  Did it not occur to you that the US hasn't experienced worse violence because we have been prudent about using military force?  And of course Obama asked Congress for authorization to do more; he didn't get it.  The truth is that violence begets more violence, especially as Europe and the US react with vengeance so far beyond reciprocity for tiny attacks.  And it's really rare with modern guerrilla warfare for traditional wars to reach any kind of positive outcome.  It's time for new solutions.  Stop beating the drums of war!

I totally agree with you. Both parties are gasping their last breath. The Soviet Union collapsed almost 30 years ago. It's our turn now.

Here's an interview with Mikhail Gorbachev 7 months ago where he is talking about how America has lost its way.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQmx8cPdIrk

As a resident of Wisconsin, my vote doesn't count in the primaries. In the last one, Obama was going to win before the vote got here, but I still voted for Clinton.

In this one, Cinton will be the winner before it gets here, so my vote doesn't matter in this one either. The only thing I can do to be heard is to vote against the party that doesn't count my vote.

So I'm voting for Trump. That's my final decision. It is the only way to be heard by a totally corrupt party system and a totally corrupt press.

There will be a new hope eventually, but it won't come from your party or you're worn out ideas.

Superdelegates? Supercorrupt.

While I'm sure Gail misses Seamus, I'm also sure #HeWhoMustNotBeNamed gives her ample fodder for her column. I do wish the conversations with Arthur Brooks were a little less lopsided, though... he tends to monopolize the space.

And I'm very glad you don't have to use "Mister" to write about anyone.

I agree. I was able to get this one fairly quickly for a Wednesday, and then sat scratching my head (as Deb did) wondering what about the theme clues was TRIPLE TIME. And then the little light went off in my head.

Very clever puzzle!

and Elke

Bed TIME- it's been a long day.
Thanks. still seems silly to me though.
Darn!  I thoroughly enjoyed your recaps.  I'm fairly new to reading the Times online and just now discovered I could make a comment.
I have never been able to get a decent rise out of a sourdough starter even though I've had some supposedly well-established or even commercially available starters... thoughts, help?

The only thing I can suggest is making sure you are proofing at an adequate temperature.   Some ovens have a proofing mode, where the temperature is around 80 degrees.  You can also build a proofing box by using a low wattage light bulb with a dimmer switch and thermometer in a styrofoam container, and trying to proof at higher temperatures- experiment from 75-90 degrees.  When I made my own local sourdough starter in Brazil the temperature was probably in the 80s or higher which is one reason it did so well.  A room temperature of 68 or even 72 is too low to really get cultures fully activated.  When you activate your culture you should see it rise "exponentially" as it rises and bubbles up and peaks then starts shrinking down as it starts to run out of the sugar needed for growing with the shortest doubling time.

I was wondering if that guy was still around (at Sourdoughs International)!

I bought, via mail order in the late '80s, three of the packaged starters as offered by Sourdoughs International. Of the two starters I've still got going, one is the Russian starter offered on the sourdo.com website from that initial order. The other is a recipe using Champagne grapes I got from Steve Singleton's method as described in "Chez Panisse Cookbook," by Alice Waters.

I agree with both the article and commenters that started adopt and adapt to local ingredients and atmosphere. I must say, that my two starters, although fed from the same trough, bear distinct qualities: one is sweet and mildly sour, the other quite pungent and bolder (the Russian).

-- Randy

There is an excellent website called sourdo.com which sells sourdough cultures from all over the world. I use the one they got from a centuries old bakery on the Island of Ischia in Italy, and it makes great Italian bread and pizza that tastes like the stuff you get in Naples (I also use an oven that gets un to 900 degrees go it bakes in a few minutes the way they do it there). This is a sourdough which is not very sour. When on vacation in Brazil I have started my own culture by simply putting out a flour and water mixture out on the windowsill until it starts to bubble, and I made some tremendous bubbly focaccia using this culture. Sourdo.com was started by a pathologist who became interested in and collecting ancient sourdough cultures, and he also has a book which explains how to maintain and "wash" your cultures, and which has many recipes. One thing I learned from him is that activating your culture before you use it gives the best results- so take a cup out of your mother culture from the refrigerator, add a cup of flour and a half cup of spring or distilled (NOT city tap water), mix it and let it rise at room temperature (or a little higher if possible - 75-80 degrees) until it rises and froths (and it may overflow your bowl)- at that point the culture is maximally active, and if you use it to make dough it will cause it to rise very briskly and make great bread.
Find the Malheur near you! Just look for green on the map and go!

In response to Rahul's comment: Indian inheritance laws have been amended several times in the last 800 years.
Notably, dowry has been illegal since the 1960s. Please read the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 and subsequently Sections 304B and 498A of the Indian Penal Code.
And the 2005 Hindu Succession Act gives a daughter's her share of ancestral property/land.
Hope this helps.
Another question: for your sourdough no-knead bread recipe, could I use a cast iron dutch oven?
After reading this I need to start my starter. Any comments about doing it on warm locations?
